title-group.article-title: Diagnosis and Management of Urinary Tract Infections in Neonates and Young Infants

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recently issued guidelines for the diagnosis and management of urinary tract infections (UTIs) in children 2 months to 2 years of age.1 This publication, however, did not address the management of younger infants and neonates with suspected or documented UTIs.

sec.title: Neonates With Fever
sec.p: Neonates 28 days of age or less with fever routinely undergo a sepsis workup, which should include 2 blood cultures, complete blood count with differential, cerebrospinal fluid analysis, urinalysis, and urine culture. This recommendation has been supported by a large number of clinical studies.2-4 Patients are then typically hospitalized and begun on empirical antibiotics pending results of the cultures. There is therefore little need for risk assessment prior to hospitalization and treatment in this age range. However, a definition of UTI based on the presence of pyuria, colony count of the urine culture, or other criteria has not been established for neonates.

sec.title: Young Infants With Fever
sec.p: Several publications have made recommendations for the diagnostic and therapeutic management of febrile infants from 29 days, to 56 to 60 days of age referred to as the Philadelphia, Boston, Milwaukee, and Rochester protocols.5-8 The use of laboratory-based stratification in these high-risk young infants is critical for identifying at-risk patients because physical examination alone has been shown to be quite insensitive.6,7,9 The criteria established at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia5 stratified infants between the ages of 29 and 60 days of age into categories at low and high risk for developing a serious bacterial infection (Table 1). This criterion set reported a sensitivity of 98% and negative predictive value of 99.7%, which is excellent for this vulnerable patient population. Additionally, some experts feel that these criteria could be used to lower the age threshold for immediate hospitalization to less than 28 days, as is recommended by several institutions.10

sec.title: UTIs in Young Infants
sec.p: Among neonates and young infants presenting with febrile illness in the first few weeks of life, UTI is the most commonly diagnosed serious bacterial infection, with incidence as high as 7.5% in various reports.11 Because it is so common, many studies have examined potential risk factors for UTIs. A major risk factor in this population is male gender. This is surprising, given that UTIs are much more common in girls later in infancy and childhood. Others include prematurity, a temperature greater than 102°F, and white race. The greatest risk factor for boys is lack of circumcision, which has been reported to increase the risk of UTIs by nearly 10-fold.11

In pediatric patients 29 to 60 days of age, diagnosis and management of suspected UTIs are problematic primarily because, as with neonates, the definition of a UTI has not been established. Criteria proposed in the recent guidelines for older infants and children do not apply to these patients because literature reviewed for this publication did not include this age group.1 Pediatricians, therefore, must use empirical criteria for the diagnosis and management of these febrile patients when there is no evidence of pyuria or when urine cultures have fewer than 50 000 colonies/mL. If criteria for older infants are fulfilled, that is, there is evidence of pyuria plus a bacterial culture with a single organism colony count >50 000/mL, decisions are obviously easier.

sec.title: Risk of UTI
sec.p: The AAP guidelines for UTI management in infants older than 60 days use a calculated percentage likelihood of UTI based on risk factors.1 Physicians must first decide what probability of infection, <1%, 1% to 2%, or >2%, warrants more extensive evaluation and perhaps empirical therapy prior to culture results being available (Table 2). Such guidelines for younger patients may not be acceptable because of the higher morbidity in infants younger than 60 days of age. Most important, with delayed diagnosis and treatment of UTIs, bacteremia is known to occur in 21% to 36% of cases.12 Moreover, these children are more likely to have anatomical defects. In a recent study of children less than 2 months old with a UTI, the incidence of major anatomical abnormalities was found in 4% of patients with a renal ultrasound and another 2% of patients who had a follow-up voiding cystourethrogram.13,14

sec.title: Laboratory Diagnosis of UTI
sec.p: Laboratory diagnosis of UTI in children less than 60 days of age should take into account both evidence of pyuria and documentation of bacteriuria. Most clinical laboratories report white blood cells (WBCs) in urine as the average number per high-power field (hpf) of centrifuged urine. With this methodology, pyuria is generally defined as 5 or more WBCs/hpf. Several studies have demonstrated that in patients less than 8 weeks of age, the sensitivity of this standard urinalysis in predicting UTI (defined with a positive culture) is as low as 30%, which is significantly lower than what is reported in older infants.15

Another methodology generally referred to as an “enhanced urinalysis” utilizes uncentrifuged urine and a counting chamber, reporting WBCs as the average number per microliter. Most investigators use 10 or more WBCs/µL to define pyuria. This enhanced urinalysis reduces the variability of results by avoiding the concentration and resuspension of solid elements required when small samples are centrifuged. Using this methodology in older age groups and defining a UTI as bacterial colony counts of >50 000 colony forming units (CFUs)/mL, sensitivity improved to 84.5% with a positive predictive value of 93.1%.15 Thus, many experts conclude that in febrile infants less than 8 weeks of age, hemocytometer WBC counts should be used along with urine culture to diagnose UTI.15-17

The low yield of standard urinalysis in this age group has led to examination of other laboratory studies that may help diagnose UTI in infants younger than 60 days. Lin et al15 determined that a CRP (C-reactive protein) of >20 and ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) >30 were clinically significant predictive factors for UTI, but a WBC count >15 000/µL was not. Although the specificities of elevated CRP and ESR were high (90% and 78%, respectively), their sensitivities were lower than desired (59% and 73%, respectively), indicating that they are limited as predictors for identifying UTI in this population.

If the urine WBC count is not taken into consideration and only a urine bacterial colony count of >100 000 CFU/mL is used to define UTI, it is estimated that approximately 20% of true UTIs would be missed.18 A lower bacterial count is, therefore, favored given the risks associated with a false negative diagnosis. Using a cutoff bacterial colony count as low as 10 000 CFU/mL hypothetically increases sensitivity but lowers specificity, yet studies reported no change in the diagnosis of UTI.11 Urine bacterial counts between 10 000 and 50 000 CFU/mL have previously demonstrated a high likelihood of asymptomatic bacteriuria when used alone as diagnostic criteria for UTI.11 Although unstudied, adding the additional condition of 10 WBC/µL to diagnostic criteria would theoretically decrease the detection of lone asymptomatic bacteriuria while increasing the recognition of UTI in this patient population.

Contamination of cultures and asymptomatic bacteriuria are additional factors that complicate a clear diagnosis of UTI. Asymptomatic bacteriuria of course does not require treatment. To reduce the likelihood of contamination, catheterization or suprapubic aspiration to obtain urine cultures are mandatory in all infants and neonates.19,20

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Clinical and laboratory assessment of possible UTIs in neonates and young febrile infants is complex. Although rates of confounding factors range greatly across hospitals, geography, and gender, in a population with such a high risk for bacteremia and renal damage, a conservative definition of UTI is warranted.

The current standard of care for neonates, which includes hospitalization and a workup for sepsis should be maintained. Beyond the neonatal age range, clinical and laboratory criteria can be used to make decisions for inpatient or outpatient management. For neonates and infants younger than 60 days of age, we suggest the following criteria to define a UTI:

list-item.p: Pyuria as determined with an “enhanced urinalysis” (hemocytometer counting chamber) of ≥10 WBC/µL
A urine culture colony count of ≥10 000 CFU/mL for a single organism

sec.p: Finally, selection of antibiotics is based on the susceptibility pattern of the organism, and duration of therapy is the same as with older infants, that is, 7 to 14 days. All these young patients should also undergo renal and bladder ultrasonography and voiding cystourethrography to assess for genitourinary abnormalities, given the correlation of these abnormalities with UTI in this age group.
